text:
Problem Overview

In this problem, students analyze claims made by students in another class to decide which claims are ratios. Students identify the ratio comparisons as part-to-part (for example, for every 10 students who prefer cheese, 5 prefer pepperoni) or part-to-whole (for example, for every 15 students, 5 prefer pepperoni). Students will look at what is similar in equivalent ratios and what is different.

Implementation Note: This problem will take 2 days. Hold a brief summary after the Initial Challenge to compare their statements before having them continue with What If...? situations.

Arc of Learning: Exploration

Standards: See your state alignment chart.

NWDYK

How can you decide when a ratio is comparing a part to a part? A part to a whole?

How can you decide when two ratios are equivalent?

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

  • Deepen understanding and recognition of various forms for ratio comparison statements.
  • Ratio comparisons can be
    • written as part-to-part and as part-to-whole comparisons;
    • equivalent, look different, and describe the same multiplicative relationship between two quantities; and
    • written with either of the two quantities coming first as long as the quantities are labeled correctly.

Launch (Getting Started)

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

If you did not introduce equivalent ratios, part-to-part, and part-to-whole in the Summarize of Problem 1.2, the introduction of this problem is another opportunity to introduce them.
